description: Recorded since 1451, originally as countre part "duplicate of a legal document", from Old French contrepartie, itself from contre (“facing, opposite”) (from Latin contra (“against”)) + partie (“copy of a person or thing”) (originally past participle of partīre (“to divide”)). Equivalent to counter- +‎ part.

entries.meaning: Either of two parts that fit together, or complement one another.
examples: Those brass knobs and their hollow counterparts interlock perfectly.

entries.meaning: (law) A duplicate of a legal document.
One who or that which resembles another.
One who or that which has corresponding functions or characteristics.
(paleontology) Either half of a flattened fossil when the rock has split along the plane of the fossil.

verbs.description: counterpart (third-person singular simple present counterparts, present participle counterparting, simple past and past participle counterparted)
